Carl,

Well, from what you say I guess the released version 1.5.5 doesn't h=
ave 
the MATLAB interface to the new equilibrium solver.  One option is to =

check out the source code from CVS and build the latest version.  
Another=
 option is to use Python, which has the links to the new solver 
in 1.5.5.
=

I am out of town this week, but when I get back next week I'll put some 
t=
ime into seeing if I can finally clean up version 1.6 and release 
it...  I=
t definitely allows using the new solver from MATLAB.

Dave


On Apr 18, 20=
05, at 12:33 PM, carlmas20032003 wrote:

>
>
> Dave,
>   I too have struggl=
ed with the equil solver, so your mention of a
> new solver was very intere=
sting. However, when I tried to run
> Cantrera 1.5.5 in Matlab 7.0.1 (WinXP=
) I was given the following
> error:
>
>>> equilibrate(gas, 'TP',1)
> ??? E=
rror using =3D=3D> ThermoPhase.equilibrate
> Too many input arguments.
>
> =
When I view the code for equilibrate it seems that more than two
> input ar=
guments is not allowed:
>
> function a =3D equilibrate(a, xy)
> % EQUILIBRA=
TE  Set the phase to a state of chemical equilibrium.
> %
> %   The second =
argument must be one of the strings 'TP', 'TV',
> %   'HP', 'SP', 'SV', 'UV=
', 'PT', 'VT', 'PH', 'PS', 'VS', or 'VU',
> %   and specifies the two therm=
odynamic properties held fixed at
> %   the values in the initial state. No=
te that if U, H, V, or S is
> %   specified, it is the specific value (per =
unit mass), not the
> %   molar value, that is held fixed.
> %
> if nargin =
~=3D 2
>   error('two arguments required')
> end
> ...
>
> So what am I doi=
ng wrong? I would very much like to try your new
> solver as speed is not a=
 problem for me at this point.
>
> - Carl
>
> --- In cantera@...=
m, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
>>  From what you describe, it is h=
ard to know where the problem is.
> Maybe
>> the equilibrium solver is havi=
ng trouble converging.  You can tell
> it
>> to use the new solver by givin=
g a third non-zero parameter to
>> equilibrate, e.g.:
>>
>> equilibrate(gas=
, 'TP', 1)
>>
>> If the third paramter is missing or zero, the old solver w=
ill be
> used,
>> which is faster but less stable than the new one.  Equili=
brium
> problem
>> usually arise from specifying very hard initial conditio=
ns, like an
>> exactly stoichiometric fuel/air mixture at 300 K. Neverthele=
ss, the
> new
>> solver should handle these cases.
>>
>> Other than that, y=
ou will need to do some debugging to isolate the
>> problem.  Since the tra=
nsport demo works, you can start with it and
>> modify it one line at a tim=
e until it looks like your m-file that
>> fails. In that way, you should be=
 able to track down exactly what
>> change causes failure.  If it is not du=
e to an initial condition
> and
>> seems to be something in Cantera, then s=
ee how small an m-file you
> can
>> create that still fails by removing ext=
raneous lines.  For example,
>> does it fail if you only do equillibrium? O=
r do you need to compute
>> transport propertiess for it to fail?
>>
>> Onc=
e you have isolated the problem, send the short m-file to me,
> and I
>> ca=
n see if it fails for me too, and see what the problem is.
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> O=
